awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Heat Exposure and Dietary Choices
awd_abstract_narration:
Global obesity epidemic and secular increases in heat are two problems facing the world.  Heat waves may have negative consequences on human health but it is not clear through which mechanisms increasing heat affect human health.  This research project will use both economic theory and data t investigate the effects of long-term heat waves on obesity through its effects on dietary choices.  The research project combines the economics and psychological and behavioral literature to link changing rising heatwaves and obesity through dietary choices.  The project will link three large data sets over long periods of time for the study.  This is one of the few studies that links obesity to heat waves with the major innovation coming from its focus on long-term heatwaves as opposed to short term increases in temperature.  This research also explores the potential mechanisms through which heat waves affect obesity and other health problems.  The results of this research project will provide inputs into policies to reduce the effects of climate change on health outcomes.


The proposed research will synthesize three large datasets: the Nielsen HomeScan Consumer Panel, a nationally representative panel of U.S. household retail purchases of more than two million unique Universal Product Codes (UPCs) from 2004 to 2017; the NOAA Daily Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN-Daily) database,  and the Nutritionix Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) dataset represented in the Nielsen panel. The researcher will construct a panel of household grocery purchases, the nutritional content of those purchases, and measures of contemporaneous heat exposure based on historical weather data from the household's geographic location. The proposed research will apply generalized additive models (GAMs), allowing for the common finding in prior literature of nonlinear effects of temperature on economic behavior and outcomes, to estimate the relationship between temperature and nutritional content of purchases. The researcher will then use these findings to elucidate the mechanisms by which heat influences dietary choices and identify regions or subpopulations for which targeted mitigating policies would be most valuable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project culminated in two projects related to dietary outcomes and environmental conditions, including both heat exposure and drinking water contamination. The PI (Kelly Hyde) has incorporated the Nutritionix Consumer Packaged Goods nutrition facts database purchased from Syndigo Inc. with the award funds into two complementary research projects: "Heat Exposure and Dietary Choices," which further develops the analysis outlined in the grant proposal, examining the impact of extreme temperatures on grocery store purchases and implied nutritional intake; and "The Regressive Costs of Drinking Water Contaminant Avoidance," which focuses on the impact of drinking water pollution on the grocery purchases of low-income households. These projects represent an ongoing research agenda for the PI studying the link between adverse nutritional outcomes and environmental conditions. This research will feature in the PI's doctoral dissertation, which he intends to complete by May 2022.

The findings of this project contribute to our understanding of the root causes of adverse nutritional outcomes such as food insecurity and obesity in the United States. Particularly for low-income, budget-constrained households who cannot afford or access adaptation technologies such as air conditioning or water filtration systems, environmental shocks incur costs (both pecuniary and non-pecuniary) which make it difficult to engage in healthy food consumption. In particular, one of the PI's main findings is that low-income households affected by a water quality violation which remains unresolved for 6 months or longer significantly decrease their purchases of nutritious grocery products, resulting in a significant decline in their implied total calorie intake. This suggests that the correlation between historical drinking water quality violations and the rate of food insecurity in an area across geographic areas in the United States reflects an underlying causal relationship.

The findings also imply that policy interventions to reduce or prevent environmental shocks (e.g. through increased monitoring and enforcement of water quality regulations) or to mitigate their effect on the household (e.g. distribution of free or low-cost bottled water or subsidizing filtration systems) may reduce poor households' risk of food insecurity. Such policies would free up budget-constrained households' resources by reducing the need to engage in costly avoidance measures, such as purchasing bottled water as a replacement for tap water. If these resources are subsequently reallocated to food purchases, these policies may also reduce the household's risk of food insecurity. The PI intends to directly empirically test this hypothesis through policy evaluation in future work.
